items.author: Christopher Brandon
items.content: So moving, so memorable, so magically produced, it's going to delight millions of movie fans and sweep the Oscars.

items.author: Sean Means
items.content: Darabont follows King's book fairly closely, allowing the audience to steep itself in the setting and characters slowly, like reading a good novel.

items.author: Jay Carr
items.content: There's almost too much there, but the three-hour-plus film permits the kind of detailing that not only brings the storytelling to life, but sometimes persuades us we're breathing to its rhythms.

items.author: Shawn Levy
items.content: An often pedestrian film, one that never inflates to the epic grandeur to which it aspires or transfers its own emotional trajectory off the screen and into the viewer.

items.author: Lisa Schwarzbaum
items.content: Excessive, but I, like Mr. Jingles, can't resist the Christmas-season cheese.

items.author: Rene Rodriguez
items.content: A very engrossing movie, the kind that gives shameless manipulation a good name.

items.author: Elvis Mitchell
items.content: A film with a counterproductive tendency to take its time...but unassumingly strong, moving performances and Darabont's durable storytelling make it a trip worth taking just the same.

items.author: Carrie Rickey
items.content: Surely a life sentence goes by quicker.

items.author: David Sterritt
items.content: Its view of spiritual healing is closer to Spielberg fantasy than religious insight. Still, its good acting and good intentions will be enough to please many viewers.

items.author: Tom Keogh
items.content: Simply a case of severe overreaching and the illusion that an overstuffed movie is an epic movie.
